questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the surgical anatomy of the lungs?

choices.text: There are 10 bronchopulmonary segments on the right lung.
Each bronchopulmonary segment has a separate lymphatic drainage.
The tracheobronchial tree is normally lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar cells.
Segmentectomy is done after locating the segmental branch of bronchial artery.

questions.solution:
In segmentectomy, the segment is removed from the lobe after locating the intersegmental vein.

Bronchopulmonary segments are well-defined, anatomic, functional, and surgical areas of the lung. There are 10 bronchopulmonary segments each on the right and the left lung. The segments help in segmental resection and bronchoscopy as each segment has a separate:

  • Tertiary bronchus
  • Segmental artery
  • Autonomic nerve supply
  • Lymphatic drainage

 

The tracheobronchial tree is normally lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar cells and mucous cells.

NOTE: Gray's Anatomy 41st edition (page 958) states that the right and left lungs have 10 Bronchopulmonary segments each.

Related Pearl: Bronchopulmonary Segments

Lobe

Right lung

Left lung

Superior lobe

I apical

II posterior

III anterior

I apical

II posterior

III anterior

IV superior lingual

V inferior lingual

Middle lobe

IV lateral

V medial

                      

Inferior lobe

VI superior (apical)

VII medial basal

VIII anterior basal

IX lateral basal

X posterior basal

VI superior (apical)

VII medial basal

VIII anterior basal

IX lateral basal

X posterior basal

Note : 

Apicoposterior segment: Left (apical + posterior) segments.   

Anteromedial basal segment: Left (anterior + medial basal) segments.

questions.text: An infant has a congenital bronchopulmonary malformation as shown in the CT scan given below. Which of the following is most likely to supply the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The given CT shows an intralobar pulmonary sequestration of the left lung. The thoracic aorta commonly supplies the sequestered lobe of the lung.

Pulmonary sequestration is an area of embryonic lung tissue, separate from the lung. It receives blood supply from an anomalous systemic artery from the aorta. It is of two types:

  • Extralobar sequestration occurs primarily on the left side and blood supply is usually from the thoracic or upper abdominal aorta
  • Intralobar sequestration occurs in the lower lobes predominantly (>95%). It is equally distributed between the right and left lower lobe and blood supply is from the descending thoracic aorta, venous drainage via pulmonary veins

Treatment involves resection of the pulmonary sequestration.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old patient on DOTS therapy was rushed to the casualty after having massive hemoptysis. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

DOTS- Directly Observed Therapy Short Course

choices.text: Intubation is done into the non-bleeding lung.
Massive hemoptysis is defined as expectoration of over 750 mL of blood within 24-hours.
Presence of significant cavitary disease is an indication for urgent surgery.
Bleeding is most likely due to pulmonary artery erosion.

questions.solution:
Massive hemoptysis is defined as the expectoration of over 600 mL of blood within a 24-hour period. Common causes include tuberculosis, bronchiectasis, and cancer. It is a medical emergency.

Any hemoptysis that can cause airway compromise or lead to hemodynamic collapse is called massive hemoptysis. This includes blood loss of >600mL/24h or >150ml/h which can flood the anatomical dead space of the lung.

Bleeding can either be from the bronchial artery circulation (most common) or from the pulmonary artery circulation. Bleeding from cavitary lesions is due to pulmonary artery erosion.

The chest X-ray is the first investigation followed by rigid or flexible bronchoscopy.

The cause of death in massive hemoptysis is usually due to asphyxiation (rather than blood loss itself). This is why airway stabilization by intubating into the non-bleeding lung is the priority. After ventilation is achieved, the bleeding site should be identified using bronchoscopy. Bleeding is controlled by laser, bronchial occlusion, or arterial embolization. Surgical resection of the involved area is also done in some cases.

Indications for urgent surgical intervention for massive hemoptysis:

  • Presence of a fungus ball
  • Presence of a lung abscess
  • Presence of significant cavitary disease
  • Failure to control the bleeding.

questions.text: Where is Rasmussen’s aneurysm seen?
questions.solution:
The aneurysm of the pulmonary artery within the tuberculous cavity is called Rasmussen’s aneurysm.

Rasmussen's aneurysm is an inflammatory pseudo-aneurysmal dilatation. This occurs during the healing of the tuberculous cavity. There is a progressive weakening of the arterial wall, in which both the tunica adventitia and media are replaced by granulation tissue. This is gradually replaced by fibrin resulting in thinning of the arterial wall leading to pseudoaneurysm formation.

Rupture of Rasmussen's aneurysm can cause massive hemoptysis. CT angiography plays an important role in locating the aneurysm.

Most cases of massive hemoptysis arise from the bronchial arterial tree because of high pressure within bronchial arteries. Even when a pulmonary aneurysm is present, the actual bleeding may be from the bronchial artery, rather than from the pulmonary artery itself.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old chronic smoker with left-sided lung cancer is rushed to the emergency department with massive hemoptysis. On examination, pulse - 102 bpm, BP - 80/50 mmHg, RR - 30/min. Which of the following will be part of your management plan for this patient?
  1. Positioning the patient in the right lateral decubitus position 
  2. Administration of I.V fluids
  3. CT scan
  4. Rigid bronchoscopy
  5. Intubation
questions.solution:
The left side is most likely to be the bleeding side in this patient. Hence, the patient should be placed in the left lateral decubitus position to prevent aspiration into the unaffected lung. Also, a CT scan is not indicated as he is hemodynamically unstable.

Treatment priorities in the management of massive hemoptysis:

  • First priorities are to maintain the airway, optimize oxygenation and stabilize the hemodynamic status by administering IV fluids.
  • Chest X-ray is the first investigation of choice. CT scan is done only in hemodynamically stable patients.
  • If the bleeding side is known, the patient should be placed in a lateral decubitus position, with the bleeding side down to prevent aspiration into the unaffected lung and given supplemental oxygen.
  • If large-volume bleeding continues or the airway is compromised, the patient should be intubated and undergo emergency bronchoscopy.
  • The bleeding site is localized using flexible/rigid bronchoscopy. 
  • Control the hemorrhage:
    • Endobronchially with Nd: YAG laser or bronchial occlusion
    • Endovascularly with bronchial and/or pulmonary artery embolization
    • Electrocauterization
    • Surgically with resection of the involved lobe

The cause of the hemoptysis must be determined to definitively prevent a recurrence.

questions.text: A 54-year-old comes to the casualty with a history of massive hemoptysis. His routine investigation and chest X-ray were normal. Which of the following you will not do to prevent hemoptysis?
questions.solution:
Procoagulant drugs are not used to prevent hemoptysis. Procoagulant drugs like vasopressin are indicated only if there is an abnormal coagulation profile.

Massive hemoptysis is generally defined as the expectoration of over 600 mL of blood within a 24-h period.

Treatment priorities in the management of massive hemoptysis:

  • First priorities are to secure the airway, optimize oxygenation and stabilize the hemodynamic status by administering IV fluids.
  • Chest X-ray is the first investigation of choice. CT scan is done only in hemodynamically stable patients.
  • If the bleeding site is known, the patient should be placed in a lateral decubitus position with the bleeding side down to prevent aspiration into the unaffected lung. Supplemental oxygen should be given.
  • If large-volume bleeding continues or the airway is compromised, the patient should be intubated and undergo an emergency bronchoscopy.
  • The bleeding site is localized using flexible/rigid bronchoscopy. 
  • Control the hemorrhage:
    • Endobronchially with Nd: YAG laser or bronchial occlusion
    • Endovascularly with bronchial and/or pulmonary artery embolization
    • Electrocauterization
    • Surgically with resection of the involved lobe

The cause of the hemoptysis must be determined to definitively prevent a recurrence.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with h/o sudden breathlessness while watching television. Upon examination, he is noticed to be 6 ft tall and very lean. He is not breathless at the moment. Chest X-ray reveals a right-sided pneumothorax of 1.5 cm. He does not smoke or drink. Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of primary pneumothorax. The next step would be to discharge and follow up in 2-4 weeks as the size is <2cm.

Pneumothorax is the abnormal accumulation of air in the pleural space. It can be primary or secondary.

Primary pneumothorax can occur spontaneously due to rupture of the apical blebs. Risk factors include:

  • Males > Females
  • Young, tall, and thin individuals
  • Family history
  • Smoking

It resolves spontaneously hence just follow-up is usually needed in most cases.

Secondary pneumothorax occurs due to some underlying pathology. Risk factors include:

  • Age> 50 years
  • Smoking
  • COPD
  • Asthma
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Infection (pneumonia, abscess, and tuberculosis)
  • Interstitial lung disease
  • Connective tissue disease
  • Procedures (subclavian lines, thoracentesis, bronchoscopy, and mechanical ventilation)  
  • Blunt trauma

Patients with pneumothorax present with acute dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. A physical examination will reveal:

  • An enlarged hemithorax
  • Decreased chest movements
  • Hyper-resonance on percussion
  • Absent vocal fremitus
  • Diminished breath sounds

Diagnosis is made by chest X-ray (best initial test), CT scan, or USG.

Management of pneumothorax:

  • Primary pneumothorax
    • <2 cm size: Discharge and follow-up in 2-4 weeks
    • >2 cm size and/or breathless: Aspirate with 16 G cannula → If fails, place a chest drain of size 8-14 Fr
  • Secondary pneumothorax
    • <1 cm size: High-flow oxygen with observation for 24 hours
    • 1-2 cm size: Aspirate with 16 G cannula → If fails, place a chest drain of size 8-14 Fr
    • >2 cm size: Place chest drain of size 8-14 Fr

questions.text:
The ultrasound diagnosis of pneumothorax depends on :
  1. Presence of Quad sign
  2. Absence of Sliding sign
  3. Presence of Seashore sign
  4. Absence of Comet-tail artifacts
  5. Presence of a barcode sign
questions.solution:
The ultrasound diagnosis of pneumothorax depends on the presence of barcode sign, absence of the sliding lung and absence of comet-tail artifacts that are seen in relation to a normal lung–pleural interface.

Normally, lung sliding corresponds to the to-and-fro movement of the visceral pleura on the parietal pleura that occurs with respiration. It is a dynamic sign and can be identified on ultrasound as horizontal movement along the pleural line.

In pneumothorax, the air separates visceral and parietal pleura and prevents visualization of visceral pleura. Hence lung sliding is absent and typical to and fro movement and shimmering of the pleural lines will not be present.

Comet tail artifacts are seen in the normal lungs due to the acoustic impedance differences between water and air, whereas it is absent in pneumothorax. 

The image given below shows a sliding sign seen in a normal lung.  

Option A: The quad sign is seen in pleural effusion. It consists of four lines representing the pleura, rib, fluid, and lung. 

Option C: The motionless portion of the chest above the pleural line creates horizontal ‘waves,’ and the sliding below the pleural line creates a granular pattern, the ‘sand’. The resultant picture is one that resembles waves crashing onto the sand and is therefore called the ‘seashore sign’ and is present in normal lungs.

questions.text: A patient presents with breathlessness to the casualty after a motorcycle accident. On examination, the left chest is hyper-resonant on percussion and shows reduced air entry over the same side. His pulse is 110 bpm, RR - 25/min, BP - 80/45mmHg, and JVP was elevated.  What will be your immediate management?

choices.text: Insert a wide bore needle in 5th intercostal space anterior to the mid axillary line
Insert a chest tube in the 5th intercostal space in the anterior axillary line

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. The first line of management in tension pneumothorax is to insert a wide-bore needle in the 5th intercostal space just anterior to the midaxillary line.

Pneumothorax is the abnormal accumulation of air in the pleural space. Tension pneumothorax develops when air enters the pleural space through a point that acts as a one-way valve. More and more air enters with every breath without any way for the air to escape. This is a medical emergency where the patient can quickly deteriorate. 

A patient with pneumothorax presents with acute dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. A physical examination will reveal:

  • An enlarged hemithorax
  • Decreased chest movements
  • Hyper-resonance on percussion
  • Absent vocal fremitus
  • Diminished breath sounds

In addition to the above findings, a tension pneumothorax would also have the following:

  • Deviation of trachea to the opposite side
  • Distended neck vein
  • Cyanosis
  • Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise:
    • Hypotension
    • Tachycardia
    • Low O2 saturation
    • Loss of consciousness

A diagnosis of tension pneumothorax is usually made based on the clinical findings. If the tension in the pleural cavity is not relieved, the patient can die due to hemodynamic collapse. Hence, treatment should never be delayed waiting for radiological confirmation.

The management of tension pneumothorax is to convert a tension pneumothorax into a simple pneumothorax. This can be done by rapid decompression using a wide-bore cannula on the affected side, followed by the insertion of a chest tube for definitive management.

The safest site for insertion of a drain is in the triangle (Triangle of safety) that lies:

  • Anterior to the mid-axillary line
  • Above the level of the nipple
  • Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle

Note:

If immediate management is asked, the answer will be to insert a wide-bore needle in the 5th intercostal space in the midaxillary line.

If definitive management is asked, the answer will be to insert an intercostal tube in the triangle of safety.

Recent update:

According to ATLS 10th edition:

  • In adults, needle thoracotomy location changed to 5th ICS at the midaxillary line from 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • In the pediatric age group, thoracotomy location remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a stab wound to his right chest following a fight at the local bar. His vitals are normal. On examination, the trachea is central and a penetrating wound is noted on the right chest. A sucking sound is heard during inspiration. Which of the following is the initial management in this case?

choices.text: Occlusive dressing tapped on the 3 sides
Placing chest drain at the site of the wound

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of open pneumothorax. Initial management, in this case, is to apply occlusive dressing taped on the 3 sides.

Open pneumothorax is due to a large open defect in the chest, making intrathoracic pressure equal to atmospheric pressure. In this defect, the air is preferentially drawn through the defect, rather than through the trachea. Air gets accumulated causing pneumothorax leading to hypoventilation and hypoxia. It acts as a sucking chest wound. Sucking sound during inspiration is characteristic.

It is managed initially with the application of a sterile occlusive dressing tapped on the 3 sides. Then a chest tube is inserted at a different site, away from the wound.

questions.text: A patient presents with a productive cough, fever, and breathlessness. On examination, decreased breath sounds and dull note on percussion is noted on the left side. A chest X-ray is given below. USG-guided aspiration revealed frank pus. Chest tube was inserted but there was no improvement in symptoms. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of empyema thoracis. Symptoms failed to resolve on treatment with chest tube insertion, hence it is managed by VATS debridement.

Empyema thoracis is an infection of the pleural space. It commonly progresses from an acute phase with thin fluid that can be drained completely with a chest tube or small-bore catheter to a more turbid and thick fluid that might loculate. It is an exudative effusion. It can be caused due to:

  • Underlying infection of the lung (pneumonia or abscess)
  • Complication after chest surgery
  • Infected hemothorax
  • Complication of Pleural effusion
  • Trauma (esophageal perforation)
  • Osteomyelitis of ribs

An empyema thoracis on chest x-ray can mimic a pleural effusion or a lung abscess.

The procedure VATS (Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery) is used in the debridement of empyema. At the end of the procedure, chest drains are placed for dependent drainage. 

If VATS fails to re-expand the lung after drainage, a more radical procedure (decortication) may be done.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for performing thoracotomy in patients with blunt chest injury?

choices.text: >1500 ml drainage after placing an intercostal tube
Continuous bleeding through intercostal tube of more than 200 ml/hour for three or more hours

questions.solution:
A rib fracture is not an indication for thoracotomy.

Indications for thoracotomy:

  • Initial tube thoracostomy drainage of >1000 ml (penetrating injury) or >1500 ml (blunt injury) of frank blood
  • Ongoing tube thoracostomy drainage of >200 ml/ hr for 3 consecutive hours in non-coagulopathic patients with hemothorax
  • Caked hemothorax despite the placement of two chest tubes
  • Massive air leak from chest tube with inadequate ventilation
  • Open pneumothorax
  • Great vessel injury
  • Pericardial tamponade
  • Cardiac herniation
  • Tracheobronchial injury
  • Esophageal perforation

questions.text: All of the following will be your differential diagnosis in a patient with anterior mediastinal mass except:
questions.solution:
Neurogenic tumors are found in the posterior mediastinum and not in the anterior mediastinum.

They are the most common primary tumors of the posterior mediastinum. Schwannomas and Neurilemomas are the most common neurogenic tumors.

Related Pearl: Locations of the Common Mediastinal Masses

Anterior Mediastinum

Middle Mediastinum

Posterior Mediastinum

Thymoma (most common in anterior mediastinum)

Lymphoma

Thyroid and parathyroid
masses

Bronchogenic Cyst

Aneurysm

Thymic cyst

Parathyroid adenoma

Cysts (MC in middle mediastinum):

  • Pericardial (most common)
  • Bronchogenic
  • Enterogenous
  • Neuroenteric

Vascular masses (an aneurysm)

LN enlargement and lymphoma

Mesenchymal tumors

Pheochromocytoma

Neurogenic tumors 

Meningoceles

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient complains of double vision that gets worse after he watches television. He also has drooping of the eyelids that gets better after a nap. Serology is positive for anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies. A CT scan of his chest is given below. Which of the following is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: It is the most common tumor of the anterior mediastinum.
Masoaka classification system is used for staging.
Tumor size is a reliable indicator of malignancy.
Surgery can be performed through a median sternotomy approach.

questions.solution:
The given clinical features of myasthenia gravis along with the CT scan image showing an anterior mediastinal mass are suggestive of thymoma. The only reliable indicator of malignancy in thymoma is the capsular invasion, not tumor size.

Thymoma is the most common mediastinal tumor and is derived from the thymus gland. Thymomas vary in behavior from benign to aggressively invasive. Masoaka classification system is used to stage thymomas.

Myasthenia gravis is often related to thymomas. Symptoms of myasthenia gravis improve after excision of the thymus gland even in the absence of a thymoma. 

Complete thymectomy is the treatment for thymoma. It can be performed by two approaches:

  • A median sternotomy approach
  • A transcervical approach with or without an additional VATS procedure (Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery) for smaller thymomas

questions.text: Which stage of Masaoka staging does a patient with thymoma invading the great vessels come under?
questions.solution:
Thymoma invading great vessels come under stage III of the Masaoka staging system.

Masaoka staging system is the most commonly accepted staging system for thymoma. It is based on the presence or absence of gross or microscopic invasion of the capsule and of surrounding structures, and metastasis.

Stage

Features

Stage I

Encapsulated tumor with no gross or microscopic evidence of capsular invasion

Stage II

Gross capsular invasion or invasion into the mediastinal fat or pleura or microscopic capsular invasion

Stage III

Gross invasion into the pericardium, great vessels, or lung

Stage IVA

Pleural or pericardial dissemination

Stage IVB

Lymphogenous or hematogenous metastasis

questions.text: A toddler with cough and progressive breathing difficulty was found to have a  poorly defined solid mass in the mediastinum. What is the most common mediastinal mass in this age group?
questions.solution:
The most common mediastinal mass in young children is neurogenic tumors (50%-60%). In most cases (< 4 years of age), they are invariably malignant.

The most common mediastinal masses in adults are thymomas and thymic cysts.

questions.text: Lymphomas most commonly aﬀect which compartment of the mediastinum?
questions.solution:
Lymphoma most commonly occurs in the anterior mediastinum. Occasional involvement of the middle compartment and rare involvement of posterior mediastinum is seen.

Chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy results in a cure rate of up to 90% for early-stage Hodgkin’s disease and up to 60% for more advanced stages.

Note:

  • Most common tumor of the middle mediastinum: Lymphoma.
  • Most common mass of the middle mediastinum: Pericardial Cyst.

questions.text: What is the most common benign tumor of the lung?
questions.solution:
The most common benign tumor of the lung is hamartoma.

Hamartoma is a developmental abnormality containing mesothelial and endothelial elements. They are manifested by the overgrowth of cartilage. It is typically seen in 40-60 years of age, more common in males.

It is usually seen in the periphery of the lung and grows slowly. Popcorn calcification in chest X-ray is suggestive of a hamartoma.

Chest X-ray showing a popcorn calcification in the apex of the right lung.

 

Diagnosis and definitive treatment are achieved by excision of the lesion.

Gross specimen showing hamartoma of the lung.

Note: Popcorn calcification is also seen in:

  • Chondroid lesions like chondrosarcoma
  • Fibrous dysplasia
  • Fibroadenoma breast
  • Calcified uterine fibroid
  • Metaphyses and epiphyses of long bones of children with osteogenesis imperfecta

questions.text: Which of the following is true about bronchial carcinoid?
questions.solution:
Bronchial carcinoid is usually asymptomatic.

Bronchial carcinoids are the most indolent of the spectrum of pulmonary neuroendocrine tumors. They arise from the Kulchitsky cells in the bronchial epithelium. Most tumors are confined to the main stem bronchus and commonly project into the lumen. It is associated with MEN 1.

Most patients affected are <40 years and it is not related to smoking. It is usually asymptomatic and only 10% of bronchial carcinoids give rise to carcinoid syndrome which is characterized by intermittent attacks of:

  • Diarrhea
  • Flushing
  • Bronchospasm
  • Cyanosis

Bronchial carcinoids follow a relatively benign course and do not metastasize to distant sites. They have a good prognosis and can be easily resected.

questions.text: In patients with lung cancer, presence of which of the following indicates an immune-mediated paraneoplastic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Peripheral neuropathy is an immune-mediated paraneoplastic syndrome. It is due to the secretion of antigens normally expressed only by the nervous system which leads to antibodies production against CNS.

Lung cancers are capable of producing a variety of paraneoplastic syndromes. They may produce symptoms even before any local symptoms are produced by the primary tumor, thereby aiding in early diagnosis. 

Paraneoplastic syndromes in lung cancer:

System Paraneoplastic syndromes
Endocrine
  • Hypercalcemia (ectopic parathyroid hormone)
  • Cushing’s syndrome
  • SIADH
  • Carcinoid syndrome
  • Hyperthyroidism
Neurologic
  • Subacute cerebellar degeneration
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Autonomic neuropathy
  • Optic neuritis
Skeletal
  • Clubbing
  • Pulmonary hypertrophic osteoarthropathy
Hematologic
  • Anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Eosinophilia
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
Cutaneous
  • Acanthosis nigricans
  • Hyperpigmentation
Other
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Hypouricemia
  • Secretion of a vasoactive intestinal peptide with diarrhea

 

Related Pearl: Paraneoplastic Syndromes and Underlying Cancers

questions.text: Identify the incorrectly matched pair based on the type of lung cancer and their paraneoplastic effects.
questions.solution:
Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) causes hypercalcemia. Cushing's syndrome is caused by small cell lung cancer.

Paraneoplastic syndrome is usually associated with small cell carcinoma, even though all varieties of lung cancer are capable of causing it.

Lung cancer Paraneoplastic syndromes
Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)
  • Hypercalcemia
Small cell lung cancer (SCLC)
  • Syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) 
  • Cushing's syndrome
  • Eaton- Lambert syndrome
  • Retinal blindness
Adenocarcinoma 
  • Hypertrophic primary osteoarthropathy
Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)
  •  Clubbing

Tumor products activate clotting

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone

questions.text: According to the TNM staging, a patient with lung cancer of  size 2.5 cm is staged as _______
questions.solution:
According to TNM staging, a patient with lung carcinoma of size 2.5cm is staged as T1c.

TNM staging system of Lung carcinoma

T: Primary tumor

Tx

Primary tumor cannot be assessed or tumor proven by the presence of malignant cells in sputum or bronchial washings but not visualized by imaging or bronchoscopy

T0

No evidence of primary tumor

Tis

Carcinoma in situ

T1

Tumour ≤3 cm in the greatest dimension surrounded by lung or visceral pleura without bronchoscopic evidence of invasion more proximal than the lobar bronchus (i.e. not in the main bronchus)

T1a(mi)

Minimally invasive adenocarcinoma

T1a

Tumour ≤1 cm in greatest dimension

T1b

Tumor >1 cm but ≤2 cm in greatest dimension

T1c

Tumor >2 cm but ≤3 cm in the greatest dimension

T2

Tumor >3 cm but ≤5 cm or tumor with any of the following features:
– involves the main bronchus regardless of distance from the carina but without the involvement of the carina
– invades visceral pleura
– associated with atelectasis or obstructive pneumonitis that extends to the hilar region, involving part or all of the lung

T2a

Tumor >3 cm but ≤4 cm in greatest dimension

T2b

Tumor >4 cm but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension

T3

Tumor >5 cm but ≤7 cm in greatest dimension or associated with separate tumor nodule(s) in the same lobe as the primary tumor or directly invades any of the following structures:

chest wall (including the parietal pleura and superior sulcus tumors), phrenic nerve, the parietal pericardium

T4

Tumor >7 cm in greatest dimension or associated with separate tumor nodule(s) in a different ipsilateral lobe than that of the primary tumor or invades any of the following structures: diaphragm, mediastinum, heart, great vessels, trachea, recurrent laryngeal nerve, esophagus, vertebral body, and carina

N: Lymph node involvement 

Nx

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis

N1

Metastasis in ipsilateral peribronchial and/or ipsilateral hilar lymph nodes and intrapulmonary nodes, including involvement by direct extension

N2

Metastasis in ipsilateral mediastinal and/or subcarinal lymph node(s)

N3

Metastasis in contralateral mediastinal, contralateral hilar, ipsilateral or contralateral scalene, or supraclavicular lymph node(s)

M: Distant metastasis

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis present

M1a

Separate tumor nodule(s) in a contralateral lobe; tumor with pleural or pericardial nodule(s) or malignant pleural or pericardial effusion

M1b

Single extrathoracic metastasis

M1c

Multiple extrathoracic metastases in one or more organs

Stage T1-3/N0-1/M0 are amenable to resection.

questions.text: A 52-year-old smoker presents with cough and pain along the right arm for the past few weeks. He appears cachexic. On examination, clubbing and right-sided ptosis were noted. Chest X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: CT scan is preferred over MRI.
N2 nodal stage requires definitive chemoradiotherapy.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the X-ray showing opacity of the apex of the right lung is suggestive of Pancoast syndrome. MRI is preferred over CT because of the associated soft tissue infiltration, the extent of which can be best visualized using an MRI.

Pancoast syndrome/superior sulcus tumor results from a local extension of a tumor growing in the apex of the lung, with the involvement of C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots.

Regional spread can cause:

  • Pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction of the 1st and 2nd ribs
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis with hoarseness of voice
  • Endobronchial growth of the primary tumor may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, or post-obstructive pneumonitis
  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm.
  • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis). It occurs due to invasion of the sympathetic chain and of the inferior cervical (stellate) ganglion
  • Tracheal obstruction
  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia

Bronchoscopy can be done to obtain a tissue diagnosis.

Surgery with curative intent is offered to patients with early-stage cancer (T1–3, N0–1).

Management is summarized in the flowchart as shown below:

questions.text: During a health checkup in a factory, a 52-year-old worker complained of progressive cough and weight loss for the past 6 months. Chest X-ray showed a mass in the right apical region of the lung with pleural effusion. The biopsy sample obtained stained positive for calretinin. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Immunohistochemical analysis will be positive for TTF-1.
Asbestos exposure is the major risk factor.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with biopsy showing positive calretinin is suggestive of mesothelioma. The immunohistochemical analysis will be negative for TTF-1 in mesothelioma. TTF-1 is positive in adenocarcinoma of the lung.

Malignant mesothelioma is the most common tumor of the pleura. Exposure to asbestos is the major known risk factor. The latency period between asbestos exposure and the development of mesothelioma is at least 20 years. It is more common in males, usually seen after 40 years of age. It has a very poor prognosis.

Histological subtypes include:

  • Epithelial
  • Sarcomatous
  • Biphasic

The physical characteristics of specific fibers are important for causation. They are:

  • Serpentine fibers: Large and curly, not able to travel beyond larger airways.
  • Amphibole fibers: The narrow, straight amphibole fibers, in particular, the crocidolite fibers navigate distally into the pulmonary parenchyma and are most clearly associated with mesotheliomas.

It is not bilaterally symmetrical. Its clinical features include:

  • Dyspnoea
  • Chest pain
  • Pleural effusion – in 90% cases

Diagnostic imaging includes chest X-ray, CT scan, and FDG-PET scan to determine the extent of tumor invasion and to evaluate occult metastases. Thoracoscopy or open pleural biopsy with special staining of tumor samples is required to differentiate mesotheliomas from adenocarcinomas.

Treatment includes a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Extrapleural pneumonectomy and total pleurectomy are two commonly used surgical procedures.

Related Pearl: Differentiation of Mesothelioma from Adenocarcinoma

Immunohistochemical Results

Mesothelioma

Adenocarcinoma
Calretinin, WT-1, CK 5/6, D2-40 (Podoplanin)

Positive

Negative
TTF-1

Negative

Positive

Carcinoembryonic Antigen

Negative

Positive

Vimentin

Positive

Negative

Low molecular weight cytokeratins 

Positive

Negative

Electron microscopic features

Long, sinuous villi

Short, straight villi with fuzzy glycocalyx

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a chronic history of smoking is diagnosed with small cell lung carcinoma. Which of the following statement is false regarding the management of the patient?

choices.text: In wedge resection, anatomical bronchopulmonary segment is removed.
Posterolateral thoracotomy approach is used for surgical resection.
Lobectomy is the treatment of choice for early-stage lung cancer.

questions.solution:
Wedge resection involves the non-anatomical excision of the tumor. Excision of the anatomical bronchopulmonary segment is called segmentectomy.

Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is a type of tumor that originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells (Kulchitsky cells) in the lining bronchial epithelium. They tend to metastasize early to lymph nodes and by the blood-borne spread. 

SCLC is very responsive to chemotherapy such that median survival may be doubled.

Surgery for lung cancers:

Surgery with curative intent is offered to patients with early-stage lung cancer (T1–3, N0–1). Lung cancer resection can be approached through:

  • Posterolateral thoracotomy
  • Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS)

Complications of surgery include:

  • Bleeding
  • Respiratory infection
  • Persistent air-leak
  • Bronchopleural fistula

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

Features Adeno-carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Small cell carcinoma
Association with smoking Present, but most common type of lung cancer in non smokers Strong Strongest association
Common genetic alterations EGFR and TP53 TP53,  CDKN2A RB, TP53, MYC
Location Peripheral Central/hilar Anywhere
Precursor lesions Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia, Adeno-carcinoma in situ Squamous dysplasia, Carcinoma in situ None
Histology

Glandular differentiation, mucin production, Lepidic growth pattern

 Keratinization, squamous pearls, intercellular bridges Small cells, scant cytoplasm, salt and pepper chromatin, Azzopardi effect
IHC Mucin, TTF-1, Napsin-A p40, p63

Chromogranin, Synaptophysin, and CD56

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Thoracoscore?
questions.solution:
The complication of surgery is not a component of thoracoscore.

Thoracoscore is used to assess the risk of operative mortality in a patient undergoing thoracic surgery. It includes 9 variables:

  • Age
  • Sex
  • American Society of Anesthesiologists score (ASA)
  • Performance status
  • Dyspnoea score
  • Priority of surgery
  • Extent of surgery
  • Malignant diagnosis 
  • Composite comorbidity score

questions.text: A patient with a mediastinal mass undergoes the following procedure. Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: The patient is positioned in a lateral decubitus with the diseased side up.
It is contraindicated if the patient is having empyema.
Lobectomy can be done via this procedure.
It allows direct visualization of the pleural cavity.

questions.solution:
The procedure that is shown is Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery (VATS) and empyema is not a contraindication for the procedure.

VATS is a minimally invasive surgical technique used to diagnose and treat disorders of the thoracic cavity. It also allows direct visualization of the pleural cavity. 

Lung biopsy and recurrent pneumothorax are the most frequent indications for VATS. Other conditions where VATS is used include:

  • Malignancies
  • Empyema
  • Oesophageal surgeries
  • Patent ductus areteriosus
  • Undiagnosed pleural effusion
  • Pneumonectomy
  • Lobectomy
  • Pleural biopsy
  • Pleurodesis

The patient is usually positioned with the diseased side up in a lateral decubitus position. A double lumen endotracheal-bronchial tube is placed by the anesthetist for single-lung ventilation. At the end of the procedure, chest drains are placed to allow dependent drainage.

 The following precautions must be noted before placing the drains:

  • The drain should exit the skin anterior to the midaxillary line. If this is not done then the patient will have to lie on the tube which will cause pain and obstruction of the tube.
  • The course of the drain should be oblique to the skin, chest wall, and pleura, or else it will lead to kinking of the tube. 

The main advantage of VATS is that a large incision is avoided. This causes less postoperative pain and a rapid recovery. However, VATS procedure limits the ability of the surgeon to palpate the lung to identify occult metastases.

questions.text: What is the conduit of choice for the left anterior descending artery while performing  CABG?
questions.solution:
The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) or internal thoracic artery is the conduit of choice for the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery. The most important criterion in conduit selection is graft patency. The conduit with the highest patency rate is the left internal mammary artery or internal thoracic artery.

Left internal mammary artery > Radial artery > long saphenous vein represents the correct order of graft patency in a patient undergoing CABG procedure.

Venous grafts:

  • The long saphenous vein is the most common vein used as a conduit as it is straightforward to harvest, provides good length, and is easy to handle.
  • The ten-year patency rate for long saphenous vein grafts is reported to be 50–60 percent.

Arterial grafts:

  • The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) or internal thoracic artery has become the conduit of choice for the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery. The radial artery can be used as a second or alternative arterial bypass graft. Other arterial bypass grafts include the gastroepiploic artery and the inferior epigastric artery.
  • Long patency rates of >98 percent have been reported.

Related Pearl: Indications for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG)

Class I indications for CABG from the American College of Cardiology(ACC) and American Heart Association(AHA).

  • Left main disease
  • Three-vessel disease with or without proximal LAD disease
  • Two vessel disease with proximal LAD disease
  • Survivors of sudden cardiac death with presumed ischemia-mediated VT  

Other indications for CABG include the following:

  • Disabling angina
  • Ongoing ischemia in the setting of a non–ST-segment elevation (MI) that is unresponsive to medical therapy
  • Poor LV function but with viable, nonfunctioning myocardium above the anatomic defect that can be revascularized

questions.text: A 55-year-old man has been in the ICU for the past 1 month due to end-stage liver failure. He is not eligible for a transplant and his doctors have said there is nothing they can do at this stage. His family has consented to organ donation once his heart stops. Which of the categories of non-beating heart donors would this patient fall into as per the modified Maastricht classification?
questions.solution:
The patient would fall under category III. 

Modified Maastricht classification- Categories of non-heart-beating donors:

  • Uncontrolled - transplant team not present or prepared
    • Category I - includes victims of accident and suicide who are found dead at the scene and resuscitation is deemed pointless (e.g. fatal cervical spine fracture).
    • Category II - donors are mostly victims of sudden cardiac or cerebral catastrophes who are brought to emergency departments while being resuscitated by ambulance personnel or who die in the department. Other sources include patients suffering an isolated brain injury, anoxia, and stroke, and victims of major trauma who died soon after hospital admission.
    • Category V - Unexpected cardiac arrest during intensive care.
  • Controlled - transplant team present and prepared
    • Category III - encompasses patients who are dying, often in an intensive care unit. These are the patients awaiting cardiac arrest where the treating clinicians have decided to withdraw treatment and not commence resuscitation for various reasons.
    • Category IV - comprises patients who suffer unexpected cardiac arrest during or after the determination of brain death.
